body:
@j1c and i talked about oosase and decided to add predict method to ase.

given adjacency matrix, A in (n, n)
and 
m out of sample adjacency vectors, X in (m, n):

ASE = AdjacenecySpectralEmbed()
in_sample_embedding = ASE.fit_transform(A)
X = (m, n) array 
oos_embedding = ASE.predict(X)

issue.title: Oos
issue.body:

Issue #161 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Out of sample adjacency embedding

#### Any other comments?

body: is there a paper or some more info associated with this?
i think this https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.06307.pdf and I think we want the LLS version. some code linked above

really amounts to [this line](https://github.com/neurodata/primitives-interfaces/blob/d2773136a7dc30777c9b90c0dd8bcd0be12b167e/jhu_primitives/oosase/oosase.py#L248) which uses the pseudoinverse but I think is faster then `pinv` in numpy
dope, I'm tentatively thinking I want to work on this
cool. IMO there's a lot of thinking to do w.r.t what interface makes the most sense here

DoD:
- recreate figure 1 from oos paper to demonstrate successful implementation
- plan for API, discussed with @bdpedigo before implementation
- implementation of API PR'd
- tests (open to suggestions/changes)
    - is oos embedding almost always within an acceptable range of ground-truth embedding? (define "acceptable")
    - do independent OOS embeddings cluster harder around ground truth embedding as number of vertices increases?
    - does the least-squares implementation satisfy the moore-penrose conditions for pseudoinverse?
    - other tests will probably pop up as API is planned out
- tutorial notebook PRd into documentation

use cases (from @hhelm10 and @bdpedigo )
- an original graph is too big, so we want to make a signal subgraph and embed it, then find the latent positions for the rest of the nodes with oos
- we have a graph and embed it normally. Later, we get a new (maybe way bigger) graph that we're pretty sure was generated from the same underlying distribution, and we use oos embedding because it's easier computationally
- (maybe specific instance of second case) we have two graphs for which there is a partial one-to-one correspondence between vertices, and we know that partial correspondence -- but some vertices don't have known buddies. We omnibus embed a subgraph with only corresponding vertices, and use oos to embed the rest.

(any more?)

I'm thinking the best way to find an API that works well is to literally just simulate these use cases and play around with API implementation ideas until I'm able to do it in a way that feels simple and clean.

the other benefit of this approach is that the notebooks that come out of it could eventually become tutorials.
